results.title: The Gulf between
results.brief_description: Fired from 1000 kilometers away, 39 scud missiles hit Israel during the Gulf War. Two people died as a result of direct hits. Twelve people died from related causes. Thousands of buildings were destroyed. For Israelis the impact of this war spread far beyond this… This documentary uncovers the personal feelings and stories of six ordinary Israelis as they reflect on their experiences during the Gulf War and their belief in the hatred towards Israel by the surrounding Arab States. It would appear that most Israelis want peace but do not agree on how to achieve this end - resigned to the fact that perhaps co-existence with the Palestinians is the only way. However, the Israelis have lived through many wars: War of Independence (1948); Suez crisis (1956); Six Day War (1967); Yom Kippur War (1973); Lebanon War (1982); and are determined not to back down from their fight to keep Israel as the rightful home for Jewish people. Contains strong images of the aftermath of the Gulf War, archival footage of the Holocaust and interviews.

results.title: Ossie Ostrich
results.brief_description:
Early prototype of Australia’s most famous ostrich and former Nine Network star from Hey Hey it’s Saturday.
On permanent loan to ACMI.

results.title: Kalee Indomitable Model 8 Front Shutter Projector
results.brief_description:
Manufactured in Leeds, England by A.Kershaw & Son, and brought into Australia prior to the introduction of ‘the talkies’. Complete with Trutrim lamp house.
1 of 2: Projector and Lens
2 0f 2: Lamphouse

results.title: Unpacking Filmscapes - The Coloured Sky: New Women II
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Yang Fudong’s five-channel video installation, ‘The Coloured Sky: New Women II’ (2014), marks an aesthetic departure from his signature output on 35mm black and white film to vivid colour.

results.title: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
ACMI’s ‘Australian Perspectives’ film season frames contemporary Australian filmmaking against a backdrop of archival classics and special guest presentations.
This question and answer session with a panel of Australian film industry figures, was held on Saturday 7th September 2013 as Part 2 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’, following a screening of Nigel Buesst’s 1971 film ‘Bonjour Balwyn’.
Hosted by Rochelle Siemienowicz, the panel included Nigel Buesst, Peter Hourigan, Alan Finney and John Flaus.
The discussion highlights the key role of Melbourne, and Carlton in particular, as a centre for independent filmmaking in the 1960s and 1970s. The memories and anecdotes recounted by the panellists illustrate the vibrancy and creative energy of the Melbourne scene and the socio-economic context that allowed it to flourish.
NOTE: Part 1 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’ was an August 2013 screening of Brian Davies’ 1966 film ‘Pudding Thieves’.
